results.title: Blueprint for the future: Melbourne 1985
results.brief_description: Describes the Master Plan intended to cope with Melbourne’s traffic situation in 1985. Intense survey work has been carried out, the information analysed in computers and the appropriate plans made, mainly in the form of overpasses and freeways. Stresses the need for a revitalised public transport system as well as roads. Underground railways and streamlined trains and buses are needed. Includes plans for St Kilda Junction, Westgate Bridge and the Melbourne Loop system. Narrated by Leonard Teale.

results.title: Blueprint for survival
results.creator_credit: Mantis Wildlife Films, Densey Clyne and Jim Frazier
results.brief_description: Shows the development of moth, beetle, lacewing and fly larvae, through periodic shedding of the rigid outer coating. Stages in nymphal development of the grasshopper, praying mantis, phasmid and sucking bug, final moult of a cicada and tree cricket and emergence of a butterfly are shown. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.

results.title: Bluegrass country
results.brief_description: A film of the annual Bluegrass Music Festival at Berryville, Virginia. Conveys the history of this indigenous American folk-music through the high-energy performances of the professional musicans and impromtu jam sessions of their fans. The performers discuss their music. No other credits available.

results.title: Blue water challenge
results.creator_credit: Ronald Mason and Academy Film Productions
results.brief_description: A stimulating and accurate portrayal of the Golden Fleece Great Circle Yacht Race, which makes a clockwise circumnavigation of Tasmania. Starting off Portsea, Victoria, in January 1980, a fleet of Australia’s leading ocean racing yachts sailon a course of over 800 miles of challenging stretches of water. It has now become the longest race which starts and finishes in Australia. No other credits available.

results.title: Blue watch
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Living with Danger”.
One of the BBC series “Living with Danger” this film deals with the work of the Fire Service in the United Kingdom. The routine training courses and varied duties for full-time and part-time recruits are shown, and the highly disciplined teams of modern fire-fighters are also revealed as family and home-loving men, with spare time activities and individual hobbies. Culminates in a spectacular fire-fighting operation against a quickly spreading factory fire.

results.title: Blue velvet (Special edition) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Fred Caruso, De Laurentiis Entertainment Group and David Lynch
results.brief_description: A cult classic, set in a small American town, “Blue velvet” is a disturbing, sensuous mystery concerning four very different individuals - Dorothy (Isabella Rossellini), the haunting cabaret singer with a dark and deadly secret; Sandy (Laura Dern), the detective’s daughter, who embodies the innocence in all of us; Jeffrey (Kyle McLachlan), the naive college student with a penchant for mysteries, and finally, Frank (Dennis Hopper), the psychotic killer fuelled by his own sexual fantasies.

results.title: Blue studio: five segments
results.creator_credit: Charles Atlas, Merce Cunningham and Cunningham Dance Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Merce Cunningham Dance Company = Cunningham Dance Foundation”.
Merce Cunningham directed and performed a number of dance works in the 1970’s that dealt specifically with the language and aesthetic of film. “Blue studio” is one of these works that Cunningham made that directly utilised filmic devices interacting with the physical human body to create a series of avant garde works that are housed within the screen. Working with film enabled Cunningham to create pieces not possible for the stage, utilising blue screen technology, animation, editing and the layering of various film stock. This approach to his work changes both the contextual and physical aspects possible in dance whilst addressing the human and physical relationship with television. “Camera space presents a challenge. It has clear limits, but it also gives opportunities of working with dance that are not available on the stage. The camera takes a fixed view, but it can be moved. There is the possibility of cutting to a second camera which can change the size of the dancer, which, to my eye, also affects the time, the rhythm of the movement…” Merce Cunningham. Reference: http://www.merce.org/filmvideo.html

results.title: Blue steel
results.creator_credit: Lightening Pictures, Edward Pressman, Oliver Stone and Kathryn Bigelow
results.brief_description: A steadily paced thriller from director Kathryn Bigelow starring Jamie Lee Curtis as Megan Turner, a recently graduated New York cop who is stalked by the same murdering mad man that she is investigating. An outcast in her family and in constant difficulty when it comes to relationships as a result of her occupation, suffering chastisement even within the career path she has devoted herself to, the start of a new passionate romance with Eugene Hunt (Ron Silver) has all the appearance of a turn around in her fortunes. However, little is as it seems and with the help of a fellow officer she is forced to confront her obsessive nemesis and her own self-doubts and fears. This film is a suspenseful and psychological drama with an unexpected and insightful angle on the nature of human needs and desires and the complexities of human relationships in the contemporary and ever anonymous city. Kathryn Bigelow develops a dream-like perspective on the characters and turn of events in the film, an early example of her fluid style of direction.
